title: Women Techmakers Berlin
subject: Study Jam Kickoff + Introduction to Kotlin
description: On this last session we will give you time to work a bit more on your projects, then we will encourage you to present them :-) It does not matter if it does not work or it is incomplete, what matters is that you tried!

speaker: John Kaster
title: Santa Cruz Kotlin User Group
subject: Kotlin Coroutines: what are they, and why you should love them

speaker: Ronen Sabag
title: .droidcon Berlin
subject: Lean way to write asynchronous code with Kotlin's coroutines
description: A very common scenario for a modern app is the need to perform several background tasks in parallel. Sometimes we want to wait for the response of all or some of them and this can be cumbersome to develop. We will see how can we use Kotlin's coroutines power and simplicity to run and manage several tasks in parallel in a very convenient way. This could also be a great and native alternative to RxJava without its steep learning curve and complexity.

speaker: Nelson Osacky
title: .droidcon Berlin
subject: Can Kotlin save me from my groovy buildscripts?
description: We all know and love to use Kotlin in our Android apps, but did you know you can also use it to write your gradle build scripts? This talk will cover the pros and cons of migrating your buildscripts from Groovy to Kotlin. Is Kotlin more understandable than Groovy? Does it compile faster than Groovy? Is type safety and advantage in build scripts? This talk will also cover how the Kotlin Gradle DSL works under the hood.

speaker: Danny Preussler
title: .droidcon Berlin
subject: To inject or not inject - dependence injection in a Kotlin world
description: Dependency Injection via frameworks like Dagger were present in most modern Android projects. But then Kotlin happened. And since then a bunch of new libraries like Koin or Kodein appeared. Developers are even writing articles how to do DI without any framework. Some argue that those don’t even offer real dependency injection. Let’s look at that argument and compare the approaches. So, is there something wrong with Dagger & co. in Kotlin? Are they obsolete? What are the alternatives? Let’s dive in.

speaker: Zan Markan
title: .droidcon Berlin
subject: The state of the Kotlin ecosystem
description: Over the last three months I ran a survey of the global Kotlin ecosystem. My goal was to learn how developers use and adopt Kotlin - either in work or side projects, or just for playing around, and what are some of the most popular resources for learning it. The survey was a great success, and gained over 2400 responses in total! The results are meant to become a resource for the Kotlin community. Something we can all look at for interesting insights that will also help drive adoption of Kotlin in our teams and organisations. To give you a taster, here’s a few questions I asked in the survey: How big is Android as a proportion of all Kotlin developers Are people happy naming libraries and tooling with K What are the favourite features of the language What kind of DSLs are people

speaker: Ricardo Lage
title: .droidcon Berlin
subject: A deep dive into migrating from avtovalue to Kotlin data classes
description: AutoValue is a powerful tool provided by Google to generate Java immutable value classes. If you are migrating your project to Kotlin, data classes are the most direct way to replace it while keeping the same features. There are however trade-offs to take into account. In this talk we will introduce how we migrated our project from AutoValue to Kotlin data classes and how we dealt with the issues we encountered along the way. We will also discuss the advantages and disadvantages of each approach in terms of build time, apk size, method count and serialization time. After this introduction, we will deep dive into two topics: First, we will look into different serialization strategies available and how they perform. We will look into Gson, Moshi and Kotlinx.serialization libraries and explore their

speaker: Matt Berteaux
title: Kotlin Utah
subject: Kotlin on the frontend
description: Did you know that Kotlin can be used for front-end web development? We are going to explore how to do this. Come eat some food and learn more about all that Kotlin can do!

speaker: Volker Benders
title: Frankfurt AWS User Group
subject: Kickstarting AWS with Kotlin and Serverless

speaker: Jossi Wolf
title: Kotlin User Group Munich - KUG Munich
subject: Kotlin JS: An Introduction

speaker: Dmitry Jemerov
title: Kotlin User Group Munich - KUG Munich
subject: Project Centaur: Using Kotlin to turn IntelliJ IDEA into a server

speaker: Werner Keil
title: Kotlin User Group Munich - KUG Munich
subject: Physikal – Using Kotlin for Clean Energy

speaker: Artur Czopek
title: Devoxx Poland 2018
subject: Do Super Language with Kotlin
description: Kotlin is more powerful every year. This language is great either for imperative and functional programming. However, Kotlin can be used also to creating own Domain-Specified Language. In this session, I will show you how to create your own DSL and use it to create applications even faster with more readable code.

speaker: Grzegorz Dyrda
title: Devoxx Poland 2018
subject: Introduction to Kotlin
description:
In this talk I'd like to show You the biggest advantages of Kotlin - a great new programming language for JVM, Web & Native.

I use it for over two years now, and I simply love its readability, elegant solutions of Java’s biggest issues, and vast amount of features that we won’t see in Java anytime soon…

During this talk You'll learn about Kotlin's main characteristics (e.g. null-safety), seamless Java interop, greatest features (e.g. extensions, data classes) etc.

But, most importantly, you'll see that Kotlin is easy to learn and makes you more productive and satisfied as a developer :)

speaker: Shady Selim
title: GDG Alexandria
subject: Kotlin Updates in from the Google I/O
description: Will summarize all the Kotlin talks and updates that was mentioned in the Google I/O 2018

speaker: Sriyank Siddhartha
title: GDG Bhubaneswar
subject: The Power of Kotlin Language
description: Leverage the power of Koltin with its amazing features and get a sneak peak of its application in Android.

speaker: Chandra Sekhar Nayak
title: BangaloreJUG
subject: Introduction to Kotlin
description: An introduction to Kotlin for Java developers. This is presented at BangaloreJUG meetup's June 2018 meet.

speaker: Duncan McGregor
title: London Java Community
subject: Refactoring to Kotlin
description:
Kotlin neatly fills a gap between the verbosity of Java and the complexity of Scala, has excellent tooling and a fun keyword, so what's not to like?

In this session we introduce the Kotlin language through converting and then refactoring Java code. We’ll code our way through a structured series of exercises designed to familiarise the audience with the features and patterns of the language.

speaker: Jaewe Heo
title: Kotlin Korea Meetup 2018
subject: Kotlin-Flavored BuildScripts
description: # 코틀린 맛 빌드스크립트 코틀린으로 그래들 플러그인을 만들고, 이미 존재하는 그래들 프로젝트에서 사용하는 방법을 소개합니다. 그루비로 되어있는 그래들 프로젝트를 점차 코틀린으로 바꾸는 방향을 제안합니다.

speaker: Suraj Shah
title: BlrKotlin - Kotlin User Group
subject: Idiomatic usage of Operators in Kotlin

speaker: Hendrik Still, Daniel Bälz
title: inovex Meetup Karlsruhe
subject: Application.kt – Spring Boot 2 mit Kotlin
description: Die armen mit Java EE geknechteten Backend-Kolleg*innen müssen den ganzen Tag lang Java entwickeln, während die hippen Android-Kolleg*innen ständig am Puls der Zeit sind und mit Kotlin spielen dürfen? Nix da, denn in Spring Boot 2 ist Kotlin ein First-Class Citizen! Deshalb werden wir uns gemeinsam anschauen, welche Änderungen zu beachten sind, was genau gleich bleibt und wie kurz der Code von Beans auf einmal sein kann.

speaker: Benjamin Monjoie
title: Devfest Lille
subject: A Kotlink between worlds
description: Kotlin is very popular in the Android community but Jetbrains hasn't focused only on the Java related worlds. They have targeted Javascript from the beginning and now they are also broadening their scope to other realms like iOS. Therefore, it's time for you to get acquainted on how you can share code between your projects. That is why, through the help of a little game called

speaker: Grégory Bévan, Thomas Betous
title: Devfest Lille
subject: Devenez un backend hero avec Kotlin
description: Kotlin gagne en popularité depuis la sortie officielle de sa version 1.0. Petit à petit, il devient la référence à la fois dans le monde du mobile (Android), du backend (Spring) et des outils (Gradle). Dans ce codelab nous allons introduire progressivement les concepts clé du langage à travers le développement du backend d'une application permettant de tester les capacités des développeurs, type CodinGame.

speaker: Gianni
title: GDG Pisa
subject: Merenda con Kotlin
description:
Dopo KotlinLab, GDG Pisa propone di passare insieme un sabato pomeriggio alternativo presso il caffè letterario voltapagina, dove poter chiacchierare riguardo Kotlin tra una fetta di torta e l'altra. 🍰

L'evento è pensato per essere totalmente libero da schemi: potete fare domande riguardo quanto affrontato durante il KotlinLab o fare domande affini a Kotlin e al mondo che vi orbita (Android, Kotlin-native, librerie ecc).

Per partecipare non è necessaria alcuna propedeuticità, non è necessario portare un PC e non è necessario aver seguito il KotlinLab.

speaker: Tomás Hanley
title: Dublin Kotlin Meetup
subject: Intro to Kotlin & starting the Kotlin Koans
description: We'll be starting with a presentation on Kotlin, what it is, why you should use it, and why we're passionate about adopting it!

speaker: Srki Rakic
title: Richmond Java Users Group
subject: Kotlin - What’s all the fuss about?
description: Kotlin is statically typed programming language that runs on JVM, now official programming language for Android development, and the most beloved language based on the StackOverflow.com. We’ll do an introduction to Kotlin, explore some of its basic features, and compare it to Java.

speaker: Vince Treur, Rene de Groot
title: The Dutch Android User Group
subject: Kotlin workshop
description: Join us for a meetup full of Kotlin. If you haven’t had the chance to get started with Kotlin this is the meetup for you. Vince Treur and Rene de Groot will guide you through the language to get you up and running in no time. Even though this is a workshop for beginners, people from all skill levels are more than welcome to join!

speaker: Thomas Nield
title: Chicago Kotlin Users Group
subject: Data Science with Kotlin
description: We will be collaborating with the Chicago Java User Group for the first time to bring you Thomas Nield, one of the speakers from last year’s inaugural KotlinConf in San Francisco. He will be presenting on how Kotlin can help position the JVM as a data science platform with live code examples of libraries and techniques for areas like discrete optimization, Bayesian analysis and linear/nonlinear regression.

speaker: Matt Berteaux
title: Kotlin Utah
subject: Kotlin Meetup
description: Deep-dive on functions. Named parameters, extension functions, default parameters...we might even get real crazy and talk about lambdas!

speaker: Yan Braslavskiy
title: Kotlin user group Berlin
subject: The Ups & Downs of Adopting Kotlin

speaker: Kevin Janvier
title: GDG Kampala
subject: Kotlin Beyond Android - Using Kotlin on New and Existing Projects
description: Learn to code in Kotlin in a very pragmatic way, while going through code examples. Join us on Friday 20th April at Outbox technology hub from 5:00 PM to 8:00 PM. We shall use app examples to practice and get comfortable using Kotlin in Android development. 1 hour to review the Kotlin fundamentals, and 1 hours to use Kotlin for Android development.

speaker: Alex Stanhope
title: The JVM Thing
subject: JVM and serverless – Kotlin at Skybet scale

speaker: Jaime Bowden
title: The JVM Thing
subject: Android from Java to Kotlin – An unexpected journey

speaker: Tobias Blaschke
title: Java User Group Görlitz
subject: Kotlin
description: Die Ankündigung der Unterstützung von Kotlin für die Android-Entwicklung auf der Google I/O Keynote 2017 bewirkte spontan kräftigen Applaus. Kotlin ist nur eine weitere Programmiersprache für die JVM. Warum also bewirkt die verhältnismäßig dröge Ankündigung zur Unterstützung einer JVM-Sprache solche Begeisterung? Was ist das Besondere an Kotlin gegenüber Java? Der Vortrag gibt einen ersten allgemeinen Einblick in die Sprachfeatures von Kotlin und gibt Kotlin-Neulingen die Möglichkeit, sich selbst einen Eindruck über die Sprache zu verschaffen.

speaker: Srki Rakic
title: Richmond Java Users Group
subject: Kotlin - What’s all the fuss about?
description: Kotlin is statically typed programming language that runs on JVM, now official programming language for Android development, and the most beloved language based on the StackOverflow.com. We’ll do an introduction to Kotlin, explore some of its basic features, and compare it to Java.

speaker: Hiromitsu Shinohara
title: 日本Kotlinユーザグループ
subject: Kotlin初心者向けハンズオン #3 / Kotlin Hands-on for Beginners
description: Kotlin is statically typed programming language that runs on JVM, now official programming language for Android development, and the most beloved language based on the StackOverflow.com. We’ll do an introduction to Kotlin, explore some of its basic features, and compare it to Java.

speaker: Danny Preussler
title: APP BUILDERS SWITZERLAND 2018
subject: To Inject or not inject, Dependency Injection in a Kotlin world
description: Dependency Injection via frameworks like Dagger were present in most modern Android projects. But then Kotlin happened. And since then a bunch of new libraries like Koin or Kodein appeared. Developers are even writing articles how to do DI without any framework. Some argue that those don’t even offer real dependency injection. Let’s look at that argument and compare the approaches. So, is there something wrong with Dagger & co. in Kotlin? Are they obsolete? What are the alternatives? Let’s dive in.

speaker: Mehmood Asghar
title: ioScrum
subject: What's new in kotlin?
description: Just developed an app in android.Want to convert it in kotlin.

speaker: Fabio Collini
title: droidcon italy
subject: From Java to Kotlin beyond Alt+Shift+Cmd+K

speaker: Erik Hellman
title: droidcon italy
subject: Better asynchronous programming with Kotlin Coroutines

speaker: Stefan May
title: droidcon italy
subject: How to write Gradle plugins (in Kotlin)

speaker: Amal Kakaiya
title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
subject: Travelling across Asia - Our journey from Java to Kotlin
description:
Kotlin brought new excitement to Android development, but the thought of converting a Java codebase to Kotlin can be quite daunting. Where do you start? What problems will you run into? How long will it take?

Deliveroo’s journey to Kotlin started over a year ago. This session will take you through their journey, the issues they’ve faced and how Kotlin can improve your codebase, your app and your sanity.

speaker: Erik Hellman
title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
subject: Better asynchronous programming with Kotlin Coroutines
description: Android application development is inherently asynchronous. Even the simplest Android application requires the developer to track asynchronous callbacks of the activity, often leading to the infamous callback hell. In this talk, we will have a look at the latest addition to the solutions for dealing with asynchronous programming on Android; Kotlin Coroutines. We'll learn about what coroutines are, how they differ from other models and how to use it with Kotlin on Android.

speaker: Alexander Gherschon
title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
subject: Kotlinify your Gradle
description: The Gradle build tool is based on the JVM, so where does Kotlin fit in that ecosystem? We will see how Kotlin finds its place in that world, would it be by extending Gradle or by using Gradle Plugins with Kotlin.

speaker: Mitchell Tilbrook
title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
subject: Kotlin Backstage
description:
Kotlin offers a modern language design in contrast to Java, while at the same time maintaining full Java interoperably: Data classes, properties, delegation, inline functions, string interpolation and much more. But, if Java can't offer these features how come Kotlin can? What does Kotlin do to make it possible to use this Syntactic sugar?

In this talk, we will go backstage and dig into the Bytecode that Kotlin generates to make all the features we love work on a runtime that technically does not support them. We will look at the impact kotlin code generations has on method count. Get a deeper understanding of how Object and companion object work and see the implications of the use of either under different circumstances. Finally look at common patterns that can help reduce the size of both the bytecode and method count.

speaker: Simone Civetta
title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
subject: Reusable Cross-Platform Frameworks with Kotlin/Native
description: While building entire cross-platform apps might often turn out to be a bad idea, mission-critical client-specific logic can greatly benefit from an unique codebase, allowing code to be written - and tested - once. Since end 2016, Kotlin/Native can compile Kotlin code to a binary form, which can be embedded into a native app. In this talk you will learn why it makes sense, and how, to leverage these experimental features and build a cross-platform module reusable on both Android and iOS.

speaker: Wolfram Rittmeyer
title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
subject: Kotlin DSLs
description:
Kotlin is not just about null safety or data classes. Kotlin has much more to offer. One of the nice things is the ability to use Kotlin's features to create domain specific languages (DSLs).

In this talk you will see samples of DSLs you can use in your Android projects and learn how they work.

Kotlin DSLs are actually made of many simple Kotlin features - some of which you surely already use, some of which are a bit more obscure. But combined together they give us a powerful way to create nice DSLs.

speaker: Kirill Suslov
title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
subject: Explore Kotlin.Collections API
description: Kotlin is out here for a while now but many developers don’t use full power of it and write Java-style of Kotlin. let and apply are the only language features get adopted. This talk is aimed to overcome a small learning curve in one very common thing developers work every day with: collections. Backed by familiar Java collection API but supplemented by a set of handy functions, Kotlin collection API becomes a versatile tool that helps to develop faster and makes code clearer and nicer.

speaker: Christophe Beyls
title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
subject: Kotlin's hidden costs, revisited
description:
Kotlin has become the default modern programming language for many Android developers, with first-class support in Android Studio. But exactly how much performance and code size are we sacrificing for making use of all the additional features this language provides compared to Java?

We'll study the Java bytecode generated by the Kotlin compiler in various scenarios in order to find out which code constructs come with hidden performance penalties and learn how to become better Kotlin programmers. Some significant improvements in the recent versions of Kotlin will also be highlighted.

This talk is based on the series of blog posts from the speaker and extends it in some areas.

speaker: Roman Yatsyna, Ivan Vazhnov
title: Mobius
subject: Мультиплатформенная архитектура на Kotlin для iOS и Android
description:
Kotlin семимильными шагами двигается в сторону кроссплатформенности, появляются десятки репозиториев с приложениями различной сложности.

Мы расскажем как уже сейчас начать скрещивать Clean Architecture с Kotlin Multiplatform Projects, как писать бизнес-логику приложения один раз для всех платформ и какие ограничения наложит такой подход.

Доклад будет интересен адептам Kotlin, которые не боятся приставок Experimental и бойлерплейта чистого архитектурного подхода.

speaker: Andrey Breslav
title: Mobius
subject: На плечах гигантов: языки, у которых учился Kotlin
description: Расскажем о тех языках, из которых мы заимствовали идеи и концепции, когда разрабатывали Kotlin. В числе прочего, речь пойдет о Java, C#, Scala, Groovy, Python, Gosu и т.д. Покажем, как некоторые из этих идей изменились в нашей интерпретации. И немного расскажем о том, какие известные языки теперь учатся на нашем опыте (Swift, Java, Hack, C#).

speaker: Vladimir Ivanov
title: Mobius
subject: Скрипач не нужен: отказываемся от RxJava в пользу корутин в Kotlin
description: 65% разработчиков, начиная проект на Kotlin, выбирают RxJava 2 в качестве инструмента для фоновой работы. Но насколько оправдан этот выбор? Корутины в Kotlin могут стать мощной заменой RxJava. В докладе мы сравним оба подхода, рассмотрим их плюсы и минусы, посмотрим, в каких случаях удобнее использовать корутины, а в каких не обойтись без Rx. Увидим, как тестировать код, написанный с помощью обоих подходов и насколько они могут сосуществовать.

speaker: Paulien van Alst
title: OpenValue
subject: Hands on Kotlin workshop
description: Kotlin is the new JVM language where all the best practices of programming come together. Looking forward to discover a language that will support you in writing readable and understandable code in the fewest lines possible? Without any help of any extra libraries such as Lombok, Guava and even more, Kotlin will challenge you to write code that even the business analyst should be able to understand. With Kotlin you can finally focus on the business features you want to implement instead working on the language itself. In this workshop, you will build a simple webservice in Kotlin and hopefully see how easy it can be to write new business functionality.

speaker: David Lucas
title: Columbus Kotlin User Group
subject: fun Unit Testing with Baco
description: Join us as we review some of the current frameworks available for unit testing Kotlin including kotlin.test, JUnit 5, and Spek (yes, in Dutch it means Bacon). Examples will be provided for Kotlin JVM, Kotlin JS, and Kotlin Native.

speaker: Gabi Bornea
title: Kotlin User Group Bucharest
subject: Kotlin Explained Series - Functional Programming
description:
Kotlin its a strong type programming language which embraces both Functional and Object Oriented paradigms. This brings the power of the two "worlds" -> functional programming in the small and object oriented programming in the large.

In this first part of the series we are going to see how Kotlin (and arrow) embraces the functional programming paradigm to lead to more maintainable, easy to reason, succinct yet expressive and concurrent friendly applications.

speaker: Andrea Bresolin
title: GDG London
subject: Kotlin Coroutines: make your world more synchronous
description: In this talk we’ll have an introduction to the coroutines in Kotlin. We’ll see how they work, what we can do with them and how they can help us in making our code look more synchronous and easier to manage. We’ll also briefly discuss about the interaction with existing code and we’ll take a look at some of the “crazy” things that such a powerful tool allows us to do. The talk will be mainly focused on Android, but many of the concepts could probably be useful also in other platforms where Kotlin coroutines are available.

speaker: Zan Markan
title: GDG London
subject: The State of Kotlin
description:
Over the last three months I ran a survey of the global Kotlin ecosystem. My goal was to learn how developers use and adopt Kotlin - either in work or side projects, or just for playing around, and what are some of the most popular resources for learning it.

The survey was a great success, and gained over 2400 responses in total! The results are meant to become a resource for the Kotlin community. Something we can all look at for interesting insights that will also help drive adoption of Kotlin in our teams and organisations.

speaker: Mohsen Mirhoseini
title: GDG Berlin Android
subject: Using Protobuf in Android apps plus extra Kotlin flavor
description: Protocol Buffers is a method of serializing structured data developed by Google for internal usage which also provided a code generator for multiple languages. In this talk I am going to talk about serializing structured data as shrink as possible using Google Protobuf inside your Android app and a fast comparison between this protocol and JSON.

speaker: Noe Branagan
title: GDG Santo Domingo
subject: Kotlin 001
description: Finalmente tendremos regularmente actividades de kotlin, estaremos actualizando mas informaciones sobre este primera reunión.

speaker: Edgar Tremillo
title: Tech Talent South - Dallas
subject: Learn basic Android and Kotlin Programming
description: Learn basic Android and Kotlin programming. Friend to TTS, Edgar Tremillo, will cover some basic concepts such as Android application components, structure, layout, the Kotlin syntax and main advantages over Java. This meetup is suitable for anyone with little to no knowledge of Android or Kotlin programming.

speaker: Yvelain Naude
title: Nantes Java User Group
subject: À la découverte de Kotlin
description:
Kotlin est un langage de programmation qui s’adresse principalement aux utilisateurs Java. Supporté depuis l’année dernière par les plateformes Android, ce langage simple et moderne a fait une percée dans le monde du développement mobile. Interopérable avec Java, Kotlin est désormais doté d’une version JS et native qui élargit le champ de ses capacités.

Après un vernis historique sur les origines de ce langage, découvrons ensemble tout l’intérêt de Kotlin au travers de quelques points de syntaxe, concepts de base et outils. Nous terminerons ce talk par la présentation de deux exemples l’un sur Android et l’autre en Kotlin JS.

speaker: Clare
title: Eastside Android Development Meetup
subject: Discuss about Kotlin.
description: We are just going to discuss about Android Kotlin this time. A lot of us use Java in Android studio. Since Kotlin is now an official language on Android, we would love to know more about it too. We all can do a quick research and share what you learned about Kotlin.

speaker: Kanyinda Kalonji
title: GDG VUT
subject: Let's Code Android App In Kotlin

speaker: Hadi Hariri
title: JetBrains Day Chennai
subject: Kotlin: Beyond Android Development
description:
This talk is about covering the language aspects that you usually don’t see in a 101 talk. Topics include amongst other:

-Generics and how Kotlin handles Covariance and Contravariance

-The secrets of inline functions in Kotlin

-Reified generics and avoiding type erasure on the JVM

-Lazy evaluation with sequences

-Using delegation to leverage code reuse

-Object invocations and lambdas with receivers for better DSL’s

-A view of asynchronous programming with coroutines

speaker: Garth Gilmour
title: Cork Java User Group
subject: Using Arrow Library in Kotlin, with Garth Gilmour

speaker: Karan Verma
title: Jalandhar Kotlin Meetup
subject: Getting started with Kotlin
description: Overview of Kotlin

speaker: Jitin Sharma
title: BlrDroid - Bangalore Android Developers Group
subject: Migration production android app from Java to Kotlin
description: Through the talk I'll be discussing about how we introduced kotlin in a live project and made it work with existing java files. I'll also talk about various problems faced at project level and how we resolved them.

speaker: Pankaj Rai
title: Hyderabad Mobile & Emerging Tech Group
subject: Kotlin hands-on for Android
description: A demonstration of how to write production quality app using kotlin. Why kotlin is important for android app developer, it's usage and features also having a coding session for developers to gain confidence over building apps using kotlin.

speaker: Ashish Krishnan
title: Delhi-NCR Java User Group
subject: Dive into Kotlin
description: Kotlin as a language has a lot of similarities to Java in structure — it's object-oriented, concise, type-safe, and designed for similar problems that Java solves with fewer NPEs. It is interoperable with Java, it brings in nice-to-have features out-of-box over Java with a functional programming flavor. It opens doors for other Java-like frameworks on the server, mobile, and browsers. In this session of 45 minutes, we dive into the basics of Kotlin and its features, comparison to Java and slowly understand the idea of mutual co-existence.

speaker: Satoru Fujiwara
title: Kotlin Android APP DOJO
subject: KotlinによるAndroidアプリ開発の最新情報

speaker: Dmitry Jemerov
title: Rockstar Night
subject: Multiplatform development with Kotlin
description: AIn Kotlin 1.2, we’ve added support for developing multiplatform projects. Multiplatform projects allow you to reuse the business logic written in Kotlin between all the components of your application — backend code on the JVM, frontend code in JS, and also mobile apps. The common code is compiled for all platforms and can access platform-specific implementations of APIs and libraries. The platform-specific parts are also written in Kotlin and have access to the full set of features of the corresponding platform.

speaker: Dmitry Zhemerov
title: JPoint 2018
subject: Идиоматичный Kotlin: от форматирования до DSL
description: Начать пользоваться Kotlin несложно — он похож на Java, и ваш существующий опыт легко позволит вам начать программировать в стиле Java. В этом докладе вы узнаете о возможностях языка и стандартной библиотеки Kotlin, которые позволят вам выйти на следующий уровень и писать по-настоящему компактный и выразительный код. Сочетание этих возможностей позволяет строить на базе Kotlin так называемые «доменно-ориентированные языки», которые позволяют декларативно выражать сложные наборы инструкций. Мы рассмотрим несколько примеров таких языков и то, как вы сможете сами создавать их.

speaker: Martin Kräuchi
title: Bern Hack Night
subject: Kotlin Hacking Night
description: For all Kotlin beginners and already experienced user: After an introduction to the JVM language Kotlin we will work together on projects to create some meaningful functionalities in Kotlin, like some kind of web services or IoT integration.

speaker: Christoff Smith
title: Jozi Java User Group
subject: You want to put Kotlin where?

speaker: Izzy Oji, Lisa Luo
title: Brooklyn Kotlin
subject: Casual Kotlin
description: how to dip your toes in Kotlin on Android and leverage the language's niceties without the daunt of converting your whole app

speaker: Kevin Galligan
title: Brooklyn Kotlin
subject: Kotlin Mobile (Android & IOS) Multiplatform Preview
description: The Kotlin/Native side of Multiplatform was discussed a lot after KotlinConf, but not a lot has been built. That will be changing over the next few months. We'll go over some of the libraries coming soon, demo SqlLite and some other architectural libraries on iOS, and walk through the pieces needed to get started

speaker: Jorge Garrido
title: Barcelona Android Developer Group
subject: Creating Kotlin DSLs on Android
description: In this meetup we will learn to create our own DSL in Kotlin, we will see examples and we will combine them with extension functions to achieve a more readable code, easy to extend and modify.

speaker: Murat Can Bur
title: Kotlin Istanbul
subject: A summary of Kotlin tips from #31DaysofKotlin
description: İkinci etkinliğimizde Murat Can Bur, A summary of Kotlin tips from #31DaysofKotlin sunumu ile bizlerle olacak.

speaker: Sinuhe Jaime
title: GDG Guadalajara Android
subject: Introduction to Koin, the DI for lazy people
description: We are used to Dagger and it works great along with android because of the compiler. But what if we are running on Kotlin? Dagger can integrate using some changes on the project, but still has Java in the way. What if we want something more… functional? Koin is a DI tool to manage our DI flow using only FP and can lead you to awesome results.

speaker: Boris Farber
title: KotlinTLV
subject: Improve your Kotlin Android build with AS Poet

speaker: Alexander Podkhalyuzin
title: Google Developer Group Vilnius
subject: Kotlin.Native: cross platform Android/iOS development
description:
Kotlin is going to be the standard language for Android. We already see lots of teams moving to this very promising language. But in JetBrains we just don't want to stop on that. So we are working on Kotlin.Native, the same language, different backend. And one of the most promising applications for this backend is iOS development.

In this talk I'll do short introduction into Kotlin language itself with description of some high level design ideas. Next step will be discussions around Native as a platform. I'll show you current complications with it and possible solutions. And finally we will go to iOS. You will see cross compiled Android/iOS example as well as example with just shared business logic. As a bonus I'll show you infinite possibilities about single language with all the parts, backend, frontend and two mobile apps.

speaker: Roberto Orgiu
title: GDG DevFest Levante
subject: Kotlin 101
description: Benvenuti nell'universo Android! Roberto Orgiu, GDE Android ci introdurrà Kotlin il nuovo linguaggi di programmazione di IntelliJ e promosso come linguaggio principale su Android insieme a Java

speaker: Jason Lee
title: OKC JUG
subject: Jerkey: An introduction to Kotlin DSLs using Jersey
description: In this session, we'll start from the beginning as we build Jerkey, Kotlin-based DSL for building Jersey applications (Jersey + Kotlin = Jerkey ;). We'll start by covering the basics you need to understand in order write a DSL. Next, we'll spec out how we want the DSL to look and work, and, finally, we'll implement it and in doing so demonstrate not only the power of Kotlin, but how well the Kotlin/Java interop really is by showing code paths bouncing between Java and Kotlin code.

speaker: Vincent Carrier
title: GDG Montreal Android
subject: Writing a library in Kotlin
description: Learn about the quirks of writing, benchmarking and publishing a library in Kotlin

speaker: Rok Petek
title: I/O Extended 2018 Kranj
subject: Android developer at Toshl: Kotlin on Android and other platforms
description: We will dive into the not-so-new Kotlin language and explore its code sharing capabilities between different platforms.

speaker: Ernesto Espinosa
title: Guadalajara Kotlin User Group
subject: Solving an Onsite Challenge with Kotlin
description: Aunque a veces lo olvidemos, una parte MUY importante de nuestro mundo son los Algoritmos. Kotlin da un agregado muy interesante al trabajar con colecciones de datos y puede ser de muchisima ayuda para lidiar con esos retos que se nos presentan en entrevistas de trabajo.

speaker: Joost Heijkoop
title: Kotlin.amsterdam
subject: Building a Spring app with Kotlin
description: Time for our next meetup. Let's do something different. I like to do a walk-through, creating a web app back-end written in Kotlin using Spring! Let's see how Kotlin can help us in an environment we might be used to from Java-land.

speaker: Asif Hussain
title: Android Kotlin Basic
subject: Basic Kotlin
description: Workshop free untuk developer mobile yang mau terjun ke Kotlin

speaker: Marharyta Nedzelska
title: Java Eastern Europe Conference 2018
subject: Kotlin: lazy language for lazy people
description: A few years ago you had to work hard to succeed in some fields. Nowadays you don’t need to work hard but to work smart. So this means that most of the time laziness (of course not extremely) is useful for our productivity. On the other hand, laziness is extremely important when you work with large amount of data and reduced space or power. In this talk we will try to cover all aspects of laziness in Kotlin: starting from lazy initialization of properties using delegates, lazy collections, sequences and, finally, laziness with coroutines. The main thing we would like to talk about is how to use this laziness and be productive with it. To see one more benefit of laziness in Kotlin we’ll refactor a real application to use lazy calculations.

speaker: Dmitry Jemerov
title: Java Eastern Europe Conference 2018
subject: Kotlin: new silver bullet or the future

speaker: Dmitry Jemerov
title: Java Eastern Europe Conference 2018
subject: Developing multiplatform projects in Kotlin
description:
Kotlin 1.2, we’ve added support for developing multiplatform projects. Multiplatform projects allow you to reuse the business logic written in Kotlin between all the components of your application – backend code on the JVM, frontend code in JS, and also mobile apps. The common code is compiled for all platforms and can access platform-specific implementations of APIs and libraries. The platform-specific parts are also written in Kotlin and have access to the full set of features of the corresponding platform.

In this talk, we’ll look at language and IDE features that support developing multiplatform projects, and at the libraries that can be used in such projects. As an example, we’ll study a project that supports isomorphic HTML rendering, or, in other words, reuses the HTML building code between the frontend and the backend.

speaker: Ruslan Klymenko
title: Java Eastern Europe Conference 2018
subject: Kotlin decompiled. The closer look to comparision between java and kotlin
description: The talk is about Kotlin features, which are decompiled to Java code. You’ll understand how all of this ‘magic’ works in depths, which benefits it’ll give to you and what you may loose. Some benchmarks are included as a bonus.

speaker: Aleksandr Tarasov
title: Java Eastern Europe Conference 2018
subject: Automating experiments with Kotlin DSL
description: In a large project, you can not just take it and make it available to all customers. Therefore, experiments are conducted that require manual changes that lead to time costs and sometimes errors. To remove these factors, Odnoklassniki decided to automate the preparation and launch of experiments. In the report, Aleksandr Tarasov will tell you why Kotlin was chosen for this, rather than the classic configuration management tools (such as Ansible), why a good DSL and toolkit are critical to this task. Make a deep dive into Kotlin Script feature and overcome problems that we’ve solved in order for everything to work as originally conceived.

speaker: Izzet Mustafaiev
title: Java Eastern Europe Conference 2018
subject: Kotlin strives for Deep Learning
description: AI is New Electricity and Deep Learning is one of key enablers for this, it breaks known limits of possible and disrupts vast areas of our modern life. From dev standpoint it sounds science-heavy and requires PhD in fact its not. Here I’m going to explain why in theory and practice with Kotlin. Kotlin is a modern language with great perspectives to write concise, safe and interoperable applications, while Deep Learning is something what we’re going to develop in the nearest future. So why not to combine those 2 powers into 1?

speaker: Seetha Annamraju
title: Velos Weekend of Kotlin 2018
subject: Workshop
description:
Kotlin is now an officially supported language for Android development!

So if you’re an Android developer thinking of transitioning to Kotlin, or just want to see if Kotlin is right for your team, this workshop is for you! Over two days, we will cover basic Kotlin syntax, conventions, good practices, and move on to build a working Android app. By the end of the workshop, you will walk away with a solid understanding of the benefits of Kotlin, and the ability to start thinking in Kotlin for Android development.

speaker: Lukáš Novák
title: GDG Olomouc
subject: Kotlin vs. Java
description: At the next GDG Olomouc event, we look at the world of Java and their related languages. For the balanced content of the lecture we invited two specialists this time. The first will introduce us to the Kotlin language and the reasons for programming in Kotlin instead of Java. The other holds the view that old good Java has something in its own right. 3 ... 2 ... 1 ... FIGHT!

speaker: Alexandre Delattre
title: Sunny Tech 2018
subject: Kotlin by Example
description: En annonçant le support officiel de Kotlin pour Android lors de la dernière Google I/O, Google a donné un énorme élan à ce superbe langage. Ce n'est pas si surprenant, car en s'inspirant du meilleur de Scala, Groovy, Go, ... et en ciblant les meilleures VM disponibles, Kotlin part avec beaucoup d'avantages. En prenant le temps avant de sortir la v1.0, beaucoup de pièges classiques ont étés évités. Dès aujourd'hui le langage profite d'un outillage mature, tout en étant très abordable pour les développeurs. Au travers d'exemples concrets sur différentes plateformes (Android, BackEnd, FrontEnd, Natif), venez découvrir les éléments du langages qui ont su nous séduire.

speaker: Haim Michael
title: Life Michael
subject: Kotlin Fundamentals [Course]
description: The course includes 90 academic hours delivered in 18 weekly meetings, that take place in class, and 180 academic hours (and beyond) that take place at home. The training material (slides, video clips, assignments, solutions and code samples) for the entire course is organized on the e-learning platform we use during the course. Each meeting includes a theoretical lecture together with practical practice (at least 30% of each meeting). The practical practice includes coding by the trainer followed by the students and coding by the students with the assistance of the trainer.

speaker: Haim Michael
title: Life Michael
subject: Kotlin Fast Track [Seminar]
description: Taking this seminar you will become familiar with Kotlin and be able to use it in your code when developing native applications for the Android platform and in general. This seminar will be captured on video in order to allow you going over the material when the webinar ends. Attending this webinar on-line is feasible. When doing so, the fee remains the same. This seminar will be delivered in English. When taking place in Israel it will be delivered in Hebrew. Each participant should come with his own laptop. Wifi connectivity will be available.

speaker: Mark Ducommun
title: Chicago Kotlin Users Group
subject: Exception Handling: An Intro to Railway Oriented Programming
description: If you think that removing checked exceptions was the best thing Kotlin did for error handling then you are probably missing out on a big part of the language: sealed class hierarchies. Whether using the optional or either, these data types help clarify the handling of both success cases and failure cases throughout your codebase. Drop by to learn more and maybe even hack around with railway oriented programming.

speaker: Domagoj Madunić
title: Java Zagreb
subject: Migration guide to Kotlin for Spring Developers
description: Quick introduction on migrating to Kotlin from Java for Spring developers. The talk will cover common pitfalls and design differences of the new environment, and is intended for Spring developers who wish to switch to Kotlin from Java, yet retain all the benefits of battle tested and powerful Spring framework.

speaker: Júlio Cezar Borges
title: GDG Divinópolis
subject: Kotlin + Anko - Simplificando o que já é simples
description: Utilização das bibliotecas Anko para aumentar a produtividade e diminuir a curva de aprendizado no desenvolvimento Android com Kotlin.

speaker: Eyitayo Alimi
title: Kotlin Nigeria User Group
subject: Kotlin Beyond Android
description: Kotlin for Android -yes we are aware - but Kotlin for other projects , are we? Join us as we commence a series of events to show developers and non-developers alike, how else they could use Kotlin outside Android development.

speaker: Konrad Kamiński
title: Devoxx UK 2018
subject: Asynchronous programming with Kotlin coroutines
description:
Coroutines is a new feature in Kotlin 1.1. It allows for writing an asynchronous code almost just like if it was regular/synchronous. This makes coroutines a great alternative to existing approaches for writing asynchronous applications.

In this session, I'll show how coroutines work in Kotlin. You'll learn about new syntax and implementation details. You'll find out about the differences between coroutines-based and reactive-based solutions. You'll also see a sample Spring-based application which uses coroutines.

speaker: Todd Ginsberg
title: Detroit Java User Group
subject: Is Kotlin Right for You?
description:
Sure Java pays the bills for some of us, but there’s no reason why we can’t have fun developing again. Kotlin, developed by JetBrains, has been catching on lately because of its functional nature, null safety, type inference, full interoperability with Java, cross-platform support, and ease of use with Android and Spring. Is this something you and your team should considering spending time to learn?

In this session we will go over what Kotlin is, what problems it solves, and what makes it stand out from other JVM languages. You’ll come away with enough knowledge to decide if this is something you and your team should consider adopting.

speaker: Jeff Butler
title: Indy.Code()
subject: Introduction to Kotlin
description: It's time to learn Kotlin! The Spring Framework has embraced Kotlin as a first class language, and Kotlin is also becoming the language of choice for native Android development.

speaker: Shashank Sharma
title: Kotlin NIGHT-Greater Noida
subject: Get started with kotlin
description: this will be first ever kotlin night for the Greater-Noida which will help developer community of Greater-Noida to get started with kotlin.

speaker: Sunkanmi Ijatuyi
title: Kotlin Ondo User Group
subject: Using Kotlin to build API
description: To give a well detail description on how to use Kotlin (using KTOR framework) to build API that has endpoints to post, update, delete, read for interacting with other platform.

speaker: Marko Božić
title: Kotlin Zagreb
subject: Improving Rx properties with Kapt
description: In the first part, I’ll explain why we use Rx and which properties of Rx sequences are the ones we care about while developing mobile applications. After that, we’ll talk about how to prove that your code satisfies these properties and how Kapt can help us achieve that.

speaker: Miroslav Radanović
title: Kotlin Zagreb
subject: Kotlin - multiplatform support
description: This talk will introduce you with possibilities of Kotlin multi-platform feature. Share same code base and business logic between different platforms, while managing to persist native app look and feel.

speaker: Burcu Geneci
title: Women Techmakers IWD’18 Düzce
subject: Introduction to Kotlin
description: Kotlin is introduced and backed from Google and Jetbrains at Google I/O 17. It will be a short quick and warming introduction section for Kotlin language. Performance and advantages of Kotlin language will be discussed.

speaker: Michael Yotive
title: Columbus Kotlin User Group
subject: And now for something completely different - Kotlin JS
description:
Kotlin on the Server! Kotlin on Android! Kotlin on the... browser?

Did you know, since version 1.1, the Kotlin compiler has offered a production-grade Kotlin-to-JavaScript transpiler? Using Kotlin/JS, we can not only use Kotlin for interacting with DOM elements, but we can also use Kotlin to communicate with server-side JavaScript such as Node.js! In this talk, we'll poke around the Kotlin transpiler and examine the javascript code that gets produced. We will go through several small projects to get a better understanding as to why you might choose Kotlin instead TypeScript or JavaScript for your application.

speaker: Barry Feigenbaum Ph.D.
title: Austin Java Users Group
subject: The Case for Kotlin
description: Kotlin is a new language designed to run on the JRE, on Android and over JavaScript. Join Dr. Feigenbaum as he presents a high-level introduction to the Kotlin language and shows you why you just might want to consider making it your new first language.

speaker: Victor Bolinches
title: Sessió Enginyeria Web, Cloud i Móbil
subject: An Introduction to Kotlin for Android Development
description: Concise, safe, interoperable and tool-friendly regarding Java, the students will learn to use the kotlin syntax to create a native application from scratch.

speaker: Brayan Mamani Mamani
title: Kotlin El Alto
subject: Fundamentos de Kotlin: Conclusiones
description: What are the scopes of using Kotlin, Object oriented programming with Kotlin, Android with Kotlin

speaker: Albert Gao
title: Code Craft Dunedin
subject: Using Kotlin to share code between Android and iOS

speaker: Sunum Hakkında
title: Kotlin Istanbul
subject: One Way Ticket To Kotlin
description: Kotlin programlama dilinin kullanım kolaylıklarından ve varolan java projemizi ve java kodlarımızı nasıl daha kolay ve functional bir şekilde Kotline diline çevirebileceğimizden bahsedecek. Sunum sonunda kotlin programala dilinin birçok yeniliği hakkında bilgi sahibi olacaksınız.

speaker: Ian Brandt
title: San Diego Kotlin User Group
subject: Dinner and a Movie - Kotlin Coroutines
description: Let's watch and discuss some KotlinConf 2017 presentations on Coroutines!

speaker: Roberto Orgiu, Roberto Franchini
title: GDG Torino
subject: A Kotlin Perspective
description:
La portata principale sarà Kotlin, preso in esame da due prospettive molto diverse: sviluppo Mobile da una parte e Cloud dall’altra!

E parlando di cibo, l’evento si aprirà con un aperitivo di benvenuto, offerto da Leva Engineering, dove potrai conoscere il nostro team e i partner dell’evento.

Aprirà la seconda parte il talk sullo sviluppo Android, dove potrai scoprire come le nuove librerie KTX possono velocizzare lo sviluppo di un'app Android come mai prima d’ora.

Seguirà infine Roberto Franchini, che tratterà delle potenzialità di Kotlin per la gestione di un flusso dati continuo da Twitter con una sessione di live-coding.

speaker: Chetan Padia
title: Brighton Java
subject: Kotlin makes Java null and void
description: Kotlin is a new JVM language developed by Jetbrains. In just a few years it has become a serious rival to other JVM languages including Java itself. Chetan Padia looks at why Java developers should start writing Kotlin today and what he wishes he had known before starting. The talk will provide a basic introduction to Kotlin and look in particular at its use on mobile.

speaker: Tobias Blaschke
title: Java User Group Görlitz
subject: Kotlin
description: Die Ankündigung der Unterstützung von Kotlin für die Android-Entwicklung auf der Google I/O Keynote 2017 bewirkte spontan kräftigen Applaus. Kotlin ist nur eine weitere Programmiersprache für die JVM. Warum also bewirkt die verhältnismäßig dröge Ankündigung zur Unterstützung einer JVM-Sprache solche Begeisterung? Was ist das Besondere an Kotlin gegenüber Java? Der Vortrag gibt einen ersten allgemeinen Einblick in die Sprachfeatures von Kotlin und gibt Kotlin-Neulingen die Möglichkeit sich selbst einen Eindruck über die Sprache zu verschaffen.

speaker: Jan-Lukas Else
title: Braunschweiger Technology Meetup
subject: Android Meets Kotlin - Mit Kotlin die Android-Entwicklung vereinfachen
description: A short presentation about how to use Kotlin to simplify Android development presenting the general Kotlin advantages as well as Android specific features and tools.

speaker: Brian Keating
title: Limerick AI - (Applications & Games) Software Development
subject: Introduction - Why Kotlin is worth considering

speaker: Pablo Baldez
title: GDG Porto Alegre
subject:
Habemus Kotlin. Mas e daí? Usando a nova linguagem oficial para Android em um app com milhões de
            downloads.

speaker: Victor Oliveira
title: Liferay dev.life (EMEA)
subject: Building a truly serverless mobile app with WeDeploy and Kotlin
description: WeDeploy helps you build from simple to complex applications. It gives you predefined services that can speed up your development process.

speaker: Bruno Aybar
title: Google Tech Lima - GTechLima
subject: Kotlin Functions: From Zero To Hero

speaker: Dmitry Zhemerov
title: JPoint 2018
subject: Идиоматичный Kotlin: от форматирования до DSL
description: Начать пользоваться Kotlin несложно — он похож на Java, и ваш существующий опыт легко позволит вам начать программировать в стиле Java. В этом докладе вы узнаете о возможностях языка и стандартной библиотеки Kotlin, которые позволят вам выйти на следующий уровень и писать по-настоящему компактный и выразительный код. Сочетание этих возможностей позволяет строить на базе Kotlin так называемые «доменно-ориентированные языки», которые позволяют декларативно выражать сложные наборы инструкций. Мы рассмотрим несколько примеров таких языков и то, как вы сможете сами создавать их.

speaker: Ivan Osipov
title: JPoint 2018
subject: Kotlin DSL: теория и практика
description:
Разработка тестов приложения — не самое приятное занятие. Этот процесс занимает долгое время, требует большой концентрации и при этом крайне востребован. Язык Kotlin дает набор инструментов, который позволяет довольно легко построить собственный проблемно-ориентированный язык (DSL). В нашем опыте Kotlin DSL заменил билдеры и статические методы для тестирования модуля планирования ресурсов, что превратило добавление новых тестов и поддержку старых из рутины в увлекательный процесс.

В ходе доклада мы разберем все основные инструменты из арсенала разработчика и то, как их можно комбинировать для решения задач тестирования. Мы с вами проделаем путь от проектирования Идеального Теста до запуска максимально приближенного, чистого и понятного теста для системы планирования ресурсов на основе Kotlin.

Доклад будет полезен практикующим инженерам, тем, кто рассматривает Kotlin как язык для комфортного написания компактных тестов, и тем, кто хочет улучшить процесс тестирования в своем проекте.

speaker: Andrey Breslav
title: JPoint 2018
subject: На плечах гигантов: языки, у которых учился Kotlin
description: Расскажем о тех языках, из которых мы заимствовали идеи и концепции, когда разрабатывали Kotlin. В числе прочего, речь пойдет о Java, C#, Scala, Groovy, Python, Gosu и т.д. Покажем, как некоторые из этих идей изменились в нашей интерпретации. И немного расскажем о том, какие известные языки теперь учатся на нашем опыте (Swift, Java, Hack, C#).

speaker: Antonel Ernest Pazargic, Gabi Bornea
title: Kotlin User Group Bucharest
subject: Kotlin Explained Series - Functional Programming
description:
Kotlin its a strong type programming language which embraces both Functional and Object Oriented paradigms. This brings the power of the two "worlds" -> functional programming in the small and object oriented programming in the large.

In this first part of the series we are going to see how Kotlin (and arrow) embraces the functional programming paradigm to lead to more maintainable, easy to reason, succinct yet expressive and concurrent friendly applications.

speaker: Artem Dorosh
title: OSDC
subject: Approaching Clean Architecture in Android with Kotlin
description:
Світ все більше рухається в сторону wearable-девайсів, об’єм мобільного трафіка росте з нереальною швидкістю, а люди ні на хвилину не розстаються зі своїми смартфонами. В таких реаліях розробка під Android стає не просто крутою професією, а невід’ємною складовою технічного прогресу.

Артем Дорош розповість про те, як писати круті Android-застосунки на Kotlin. В Артема за спиною 4 роки професійної розробки під Android, тому точно буде багато цікавої інфи.

speaker: Zahid Mahmood
title: RocksTech
subject: Know about kotlin
description: What is Kotlin , how it helps developers ,is Kotlin beter than java.

speaker: Kevin Galligan
title: .droidconSF
subject: Kotlin Multiplatform In Production
description:
Kotlin Native, with the ability to produce iOS code, was announced at KotlinConf 2017. With rapid progress on the runtime and tools, and intense community interest, several major architectural libraries have been released. KotlinConf 2018 will definitely see significant releases both, in both libraries and tools, and likely an official v1 of Kotlin Native.

2019 will be the year of significant application releases with a shared architectural base, powered by Kotlin multiplatform. This talk will be about the framework, how it compares (favorably) to other options, the current state of the ecosystem, and where developers eager to get involved in significant open source contributions can get started.

speaker: Juliano Moraes
title: .droidconSF
subject: Netflix's componentization architecture with RxJava + Kotlin
description:
Recently we rewrote the Netflix's player UI using a new architecture that allows great reusability, testability and extendability.

This talk is about our journey from a monolithic fragment to several independent and reusable components and how it is helping us to move fast with our AB tests.

speaker: Brent Watson
title: .droidconSF
subject: Advanced Kotlin
description: If you want to up your Kotlin game, come check out some advanced language features. Some of the things we'll cover are: delegates, covariance/contravariance, tailrec, sealed classes, kotlin's reflection API, coroutines, and more.

speaker: Cecilia Castillo
title: .droidconSF
subject: If your code looks like it's Kotlin & quacks like it's Kotlin, then it probably is Swift.

speaker: Israel Ferrer Camacho
title: .droidconSF
subject: From Effective Java to Effective Kotlin

speaker: Joaquim Verges
title: .droidconSF
subject: Quick and clean prototypes that scale with Helium: a reactive MVP framework in Kotlin

speaker: Roman Elizarov
title: Goto Conference
subject: Fresh Async With Kotlin
description:
Asynchronous programming is on the rise. Modern software systems are connected and constantly communicating. Programming languages are adding some form of asynchronous programming like async/await. However, Kotlin had taken a fresh approach to this problem with Kotlin Coroutines.

In this talk, we’ll study various approaches to asynchronous programming, their evolution, differences and similarities. We’ll see the problem with the traditional async/await approach that is based on futures/promises and how the Kotlin’s solution that is based on concepts of coroutines and continuations is giving us safer and easier programming model.

speaker: Roman Elizarov
title: Goto Conference
subject: Asynchronous Programming with Kotlin
description: This workshop covers asynchronous programming in Kotlin using coroutines. It starts with basics of asynchronous programming and its differences from blocking code and introduces concepts of suspending functions and coroutines. Dealing with the ecosystem of blocking code on JVM is covered in depth as well as best practices for managing cancellation of asynchronous operations. The workshop also covers more advanced topics of concurrent decomposition of work via futures, deep dive into coroutine contexts and includes an overview of Communication Sequential Process (CSP) approach and channels.

speaker: Kevin Most
title: Øredev
subject: Idiomatic Interop with Kotlin
description:
One of Kotlin's most valuable features is its 100% Java interop

However, your clean Java code might not look so clean from Kotlin, and vice versa

We will discuss strategies to write code in either language, to be consumed in either language, that is safe, elegant, and idiomatic

We will also touch on Kotlin's interop story for other targets (common, JS, and native) and what you can do there

speaker: Simon Harrer
title: Øredev
subject: Domain-driven Design with Kotlin
description:
You will learn about domain-driven design and its tactical design.

You will learn about implementing a tactical design in Kotlin using also lesser known language features.

You will learn a little bit about the rules in dungeons and drago

speaker: Marharyta Nedzelska
title: Devoxx Ukraine 2018
subject: Domain-driven Design with Kotlin
description: Microservice architecture is now a huge trend. All big organizations with millions of users are doing microservices. This means they have lots of channels of communication between services and need to send and get much data. At some point, you can find yourself in a situation where your current approach doesn’t provide you with efficient communications, you pay more, wait for more, lose more etc. Maybe it’s time to look at gRPC… In this talk, we will cover the basics of gRPC, protocol buffers, and its usage. We will try to understand its pros and cons and where this approach could be used. We will also compare this approach with the alternatives. The most interesting about this talk is that we will have lots of practice. We will learn how to write .proto files, how to make effective communication between your microservices, and of course, write much code (in Kotlin)

speaker: Pamela Hill
title: GDG DevFest South Africa
subject: Level up in Kotlin
description: Kotlin has taken the Android world by storm since its official support in 2017. Many Android developers are coding or have at least an active interest in Kotlin. This talk aims to help Android developers level up their Kotlin skills, focussing on intermediate/expert language features such as coroutines, DSLs, and libraries/frameworks such as Koin for dependency injection, and Spek for testing.

speaker: Hadi Tok
title: GDG DevFest Istanbul
subject: RxJava ve Kotlin Coroutines, Kullanim senaryolari
description: RxJava bir çok kullanımı olan güçlü bir araç. Asenkron işlem ve fonksiyonel programlamanın bir çok öğesini kullanıma sunuyor. Fakat Kotlin fonksiyonel programlama özelliklerini şimdiden, Asenkron işlemleri kolaylaştıran ve ucuzlaştıran Coroutine'leri 1.3 versiyonu ile sağlıyor. RxJava ve Kotlinin bu özelliklerinin karşılaştıracağım.

speaker: Enrique López Mañas
title: AndroidTO
subject: Kotlin/Native for Multiplatform Development
description:
Reliable multiplatform development has been the Holy Grail for Mobile Developers since its inception. Many frameworks did appear and disappear. Kotlin/Native has come strongly, and since it is still in Beta version there are some caveats about this. Is Kotlin/Native reliable for my app? Is it production-ready?

Come to this talk to learn what Kotlin/Native can do for you.

speaker: Francisco Estévez García
title: AndroidTO 2018
subject: Simple dependency management in Kotlin
description: In this talk we will discover how we can use just Kotlin features to inject dependencies through our codebase. Using this novel approach we'll introduce the concept of Type Classes, a unit of abstraction and configuration used to architect apps and libraries.

speaker: Zan Markan
title: AndroidTO 2018
subject: The State of The Kotlin Ecosystem
description: In early 2018 I ran a survey of the global Kotlin ecosystem. My goal was to learn how developers use and adopt Kotlin - either in work or side projects, or just for playing around, and what are some of the most popular resources for learning it. The survey was a great success, and gained over 2000 responses in total! The results are meant to become a resource for the Kotlin community. Something we can all look at for interesting insights that will also help drive adoption of Kotlin in our teams and organisations. To give you a taster, here’s a few questions I asked in the survey: How big is Android as a proportion of all Kotlin developers Are people happy naming libraries and tooling with K What are the favourite features of the language What kind of DSLs are people building with Kotlin and for what use-cases In my talk will answer all these questions, and more. But be warned, some answers might surprise you.

speaker: Svyatoslav Scherbina
title: AndroidTO 2018
subject: Using Kotlin to share code between iOS and Android
description: This talk is devoted to using Kotlin to share code between Android and iOS. It also covers Kotlin features and evolution making this possible and convenient. Kotlin Multiplatform Programming is a technology for multiplatform programming in Kotlin. It supports combining both common and platform-specific code in a single codebase with proper tooling enabled. Kotlin/Native is a technology for compiling Kotlin code to native binaries. Kotlin code has seamless interoperability with native platform (e.g. iOS) in this case. The speaker will describe how Kotlin/Native works, what is supported and what is not.

speaker: Marcin Moskała
title: AndroidTO 2018
subject: Superpowers of Property Delegation
description: Let's dive into possibilities that Kotlin delegation gives. Let’s discover property delegation and understand its superpowers.

speaker: Nikita Koval
title: Joker 2018
subject: Как устроены каналы в корутинах в Kotlin
description:
В отличие от классического многопоточного программирования с манипулированием разделяемой памятью, корутины общаются друг с другом при помощи каналов. Канал позволяет одной корутине отправить элемент, а другой — получить его. При этом данные операции могут быть синхронизированы, и отправитель может ждать получателя и наоборот.

В этом докладе мы поговорим об устройстве каналов в различных языках и библиотеках, о разработанном в Kotlin алгоритме и узнаем, кто круче: Kotlin или Go.

speaker: Evgeny Mandrikov
title: Joker 2018
subject: Java 4..11, Kotlin, Code Coverage и их лучший друг — байткод: скандалы, интриги, расследования
description:
Знаете ли вы, что внутри ваших .class-файлов? А готовы поспорить? Давайте повеселимся, исследуя конструкции байт-кода, и изучим, как различные компиляторы (Java/Kotlin) и их версии, включая недавно выпущенный javac 11, преобразуют ваш исходный код.

p>Наши исследования будут основаны на деталях реализации самого популярного инструмента для анализа покрытия Java-кода тестами — JaCoCo, чья недавно выпущенная версия находит в байт-коде и отфильтровывает вспомогательные конструкции, генерируемые компиляторами, которые в противном случае требуют зачастую сложных и ненужных ухищрений, чтобы добиться полного покрытия кода.

speaker: Anton Keks
title: Mobius 2018
subject: Kotlin puzzlers, Vol. 2
description:
Kotlin is a marvelous language that makes programming on the JVM fun again. During the design phase of the language, it was said that Kotlin specifically tried to avoid some of the most famous Java Puzzlers. However, having so many advanced features, it cannot avoid introducing puzzlers of its own. This talk will present some of the more interesting nuances of syntax or language features with the help of small puzzler programs letting the audience guess their behavior. The mystery will then be revealed with an explanation in a fun way.

Having received an overwhelmingly good feedback from the previous version, Anton is ready with a set of completely new puzzlers to entertain you among all these really serious talks!

speaker: Svyatoslav Scherbina
title: Mobius 2018
subject: Using Kotlin to share code between Android and iOS
description:
This talk's main topic is how you can use Kotlin to share code between Android and iOS. We will also cover Kotlin platform development trends that make this easy and possible.

Kotlin Multiplatform Programming technology allows you to combine common and platform-specific code in a single codebase while also supporting tooling for this kind of development model. We'll see how this looks and discuss why it should be like this and not the other way around.

Kotlin/Native technology allows you to compile Kotlin into native code while also giving you an option to interact seamlessly with native platform (iOS, for example). We'll discuss what, why and how does (and does not) work.

speaker: Marcin Koziński
title: droidcon London 2018
subject: Kotlinise your Gradle Build Scripts and Plugins
description:
Are you using Gradle to build your Android app? Are you writing Gradle plug-ins? You'll be delighted to learn you can do it in Kotlin and it'll make your life better 🙂/p>

Gradle Kotlin DSL is this new thing that aims to fix some annoyances you might have with your build scripts. And if you're thinking "Wait, what's Kotlin got to do with my build scripts? Ain't that just a JSON-ish Gradle specific text file?", then don't worry. Marcin will explain that in fact no, the build script is just code (spoiler: not Java™️ Programming Language code, but close) and how Gradle Kotlin DSL makes it better./p>

He'll also take a pretty detailed look at how Gradle Kotlin DSL works for Android projects. Can you use it for your app's build script right now? Does it support the extra features (and complexity) that the Android Gradle plugin adds into the mix?/p>

If you're more (or also) interested in plugin development, writing them in Kotlin is not so new, but he'll quickly show how to do it anyway because it's great and you should try it!

speaker: Matthew Dolan
title: droidcon London 2018
subject: Why Effective Java Still Matters to Kotlin Developers
description: Effective Java by Joshua Bloch profoundly influenced the design of Kotlin yet by exploring a selection of "items" from the book you will see how it is still just as relevant to Kotlin developers today when we aim to write Effective Kotlin code. For example, consider how data classes implement equals, and you can see that it doesn't follow the rules suggested and as such is not always optimal.

speaker: Paco Estevez
title: droidcon London 2018
subject: Simple dependency management in Kotlin
description: In this talk you will discover how we can use just Kotlin features to inject dependencies through our codebase. Using this novel approach you'll learn about the concept of Type Classes, a unit of abstraction and configuration used to architect apps and libraries.

speaker: Kevin Galligan
title: droidcon London 2018
subject: Kotlin Multiplatform Architecture
description:
Code sharing options for mobile have existed for years, but most tend to be relatively obscure (Rubymotion), difficult to use (C++), or limited in scope or developer interest (J2objc). Kotlin Multiplatform will emerge as an option that allows significant sharing of logic and architecture, while still allowing easy fully native integration, and have overwhelming developer community interest. This talk explores the current ecosystem, what popular libraries and tools are available, what’s coming soon, and how to get started building multiplatform for mobile.

To talk review people. The status of Kotlin and multiplatform will change dramatically between now and October, so while the talk will be on this topic, it’s hard to predict exactly where you’ll be by then. Kevin has spent 2 years working on a J2objc solution to sharing architecture and has switched to Kotlin. He's recently released a functional demo of SQLite and SQLDelight running on iOS and is currently working on a formal SQLite shared library, which should be published later this month.

speaker: Marcin Koziński
title: droidcon London 2018
subject: Kotlinise your Gradle Build Scripts and Plugins
description:
Are you using Gradle to build your Android app? Are you writing Gradle plug-ins? You'll be delighted to learn you can do it in Kotlin and it'll make your life better 🙂

Gradle Kotlin DSL is this new thing that aims to fix some annoyances you might have with your build scripts. And if you're thinking "Wait, what's Kotlin got to do with my build scripts? Ain't that just a JSON-ish Gradle specific text file?", then don't worry. Marcin will explain that in fact no, the build script is just code (spoiler: not Java™️ Programming Language code, but close) and how Gradle Kotlin DSL makes it better.

He'll also take a pretty detailed look at how Gradle Kotlin DSL works for Android projects. Can you use it for your app's build script right now? Does it support the extra features (and complexity) that the Android Gradle plugin adds into the mix?

If you're more (or also) interested in plugin development, writing them in Kotlin is not so new, but he'll quickly show how to do it anyway because it's great and you should try it!

speaker: Jorge Ortiz Fuentes
title: droidcon London 2018
subject: Workshop: Let's Migrate to Gradle Kotlin DSL
description: Gradle is an awesome and very powerful build tool. It is key to tune your build and even more relevant to achieve the promised karma of continuous integration. However, one of its biggest "shortcomings" is that in order to extract any drop of power juice, you need to know and use Groovy. Nothing against Groovy, but it is just another language and, very likely, one that you don't use very often. But worry no more! Now you can use the same language that you enjoy and use it when you write the code of your apps: Kotlin. During this workshop Jorge will start with a walk through some of the most relevant features of gradle. Then you will learn how to transform the gradle configuration of a project to use Kotlin DSL. You will finish by extending that configuration with a new functionality taking advantage of writing it in Kotlin. Join Jorge to kotlinize your gradle!

speaker: Hadi Hariri
title: droidcon London 2018
subject: Workshop: Creating DSLs in Kotlin
description: One of Kotlin's powers is the ability to easily create Domain Specific Languages which can be used in your application. In this workshop you'll learn the basics of Kotlin functions and see how you can combine a series of features to create DSLs that can be used to represent a variety of things in your apps, ranging from configuration to domain logic.

speaker: Daniel González Reina
title: Dublin Kotlin User Group
subject: Create a Kotlin-React App
description: In this meetup we'll learn how to create a web app using the Kotlin wrappers for React. We'll see how to take advantage of Kotlin features to write expressive code that will compile to a React application.

speaker: Marie Katrine Ekeberg
title: Oslo Kotlin Meetup
subject: Testing in Kotlin and YOU
description: What options do you have for testing your code in Kotlin? Some people will probably just jump straight to JUnit as a testing framework, but did you know you that Spek offers an alternative approach with a domain specific language (DSL) for tests? Your choice of tools doesn't stop here. You have alternative assertion libraries, mocking frameworks and more that are different from what you may be used to in Java. The builder pattern is also even simpler in Kotlin, which make creating test data builders work like a charm. We will look at these topics and more! With examples ranging from small utility classes to integration tests with Spring.

speaker: Javier Moreno Aleman, Tammy Tyberg
title: New York Kotlin Meetup
subject: NYC Subway Sign with Kotlin and Raspberry Pi
description: A few months ago we were looking through a gift guide and saw one of those nice-looking, real-time Subway signs that you put on a coffee table or a bookshelf. We decided to get one, then saw the price (+$300) and thought, "Wait a minute, we're pretty sure we can just build this for less money." So after grabbing one of the many Raspberry Pis lying around the office, and with Kotlin as the weapon of choice, we embarked on a new project: Your own personal subway sign for (way) under $300.

speaker: Ryan Cooke
title: New York Kotlin Meetup
subject: Building Backend Microservices in Kotlin
description: Ryan will describe how Kotlin has gone from a hackathon experiment to the language of choice for backend service development at N26. He will present thoughtful strategies on how to build adoption based on learnings from false-starts introducing other languages to the stack. And with a bottoms-up approach, Kotlin eventually advanced into his firm's Android applications. N26 is now an active member in the Kotlin community in Europe and is focused on applying emerging features such as coroutines to their event driven systems.
